What is the main reason why community currencies have been successful?

Community currencies have not been successful, and the main reasons are the lack of essential features such as auditability, transparency, and digital wallets. Additionally, there are other key issues that need to be addressed, including the requirement for sophisticated engineering capability to implement, lack of easy and reliable convertibility into fiat currency, and no easy way to capture the Community Contributed Value.

Bitcoin itself is an example of a type of community contributed value, where demand to use and hold gives it its value, to the benefit of a worldwide virtual community of early adopters. Ease of creation and use has been enhanced as against paper currencies, at least for the technically adept. Still, no longstanding successful cases of broad local community use have emerged. In fact some, such as CityCoins, have been notorious failures.
It seems that auditability, transparency and digital wallets are not enough. Other key issues are:
community currencies still require some sophisticated engineering capability to implement
there is no method for easy, reliable convertibility into the prevailing fiat currency, nor can conversion rates hope to be predictable or stable, even in the short term
there is no easy way to safely and measurably capture the Community Contributed Value
there are no additional enhancements to community or the currency through attached digital goods and a new digital goods economy
